thread.title: Below-par Chelsea survive Burnley battering at Turf Moor to extend Premier League lead
thread.title_full: Below-par Chelsea survive Burnley battering at Turf Moor to extend Premier League lead

author: John Cross
title: Below-par Chelsea survive Burnley battering at Turf Moor to extend Premier League lead
text:
Pedro opened the scoring at Turf Moor (Photo: Reuters)     
It had all the hallmarks of an upset. 
Yet still Chelsea managed to extend their lead at the top of the Premier League to ten points. 
Antonio Conte’s men always seem to find a way to overcome every hurdle as they survived a bitter Lancashire day and a battering by Burnley who have turned Turf Moor into a fortress. 
Most managers would have left feeling happy with a point but Conte is a perfectionist and his disappointment was written all over his face afterwards. 
Conte viewed it as two points dropped and yet if it had not been for a brilliant save by Chelsea keeper Thibaut Courtois then Burnley could have easily won. View gallery 
Burnley were terrific, fought for every ball and it was easy to see why they have already won nine of their 14 games at Turf Moor which is now the fourth best home record in the Premier League. 
It made for a fantastic first half, Chelsea were sublime for the first 20 minutes and yet after Burnley got to grips with them it was a fascinating and highly entertaining battle. 
Chelsea will have few harder games all season as Burnley’s energy and work rate ensured that Conte’s men were rarely given any sort of time or space. 
They were not at their best by any means but perhaps that is the mark of champions to avoid defeat even when you are below par. Conte's men ground out a point (Photo: Darren Walsh) 
It would take a real Devon Loch moment from here for Chelsea to blow their lead at the top, even if Manchester City reduce it to eight points by winning at Bournemouth on Monday night. 
And it is hard to imagine Chelsea being that fragile because they stood firm when under pressure as it was easy to see why so many clubs have tripped up here this season. 
Chelsea actually started brilliantly, Diego Costa and Eden Hazard looked in the mood to tear Burnley apart as the visitors were sharp and deadly on the counter attack. 
It took them just seven minutes to go ahead, Hazard fed Victor Moses on the right, the Chelsea wing back rode Robbie Brady’s challenge and fed Pedro. Pedro netted the opener (Photo: PA) 
Chelsea forward Pedro raced into the box, picked up the ball, immediately despatched a low shot in the opposite direction to leave Burnley keeper Tom Heaton helplessly wrong footed. 
It looked as if it would be an easy away win, another step on the precession to the Premier League title for Conte’s runaway leaders. 
But that did not factor in Burnley’s spirit and determination. Joey Barton, football’s infamous arch villain, put himself about in midfield, Ashley Barnes created problems up front and Brady’s class gives them a bit of X Factor. 
Chelsea midfielder Nemanja Matic conceded a 24th minute free kick on the edge of his own box and Barton and Brady stood over the set piece 25 yards out. Brady fires the ball in... (Photo: Getty Images) ... and Courtois can't keep it out (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) The strike was Brady's first for the Clarets (Photo: Reuters) 
Brady, on his full debut after his £13m record signing, then curled a sensational left footed free kick into the top corner to leave Courtois clutching at thin air. 
Conte will be happy to see the back of Brady for a while as the Republic of Ireland midfielder scored the winner to beat Italy at the Euros last summer. 
Suddenly, it was a real battle as Barnes caught Cesar Azpilicueta with his forearm while Costa and Barton were involved in a grappling match. You might have known those two would have a squabble at some stage. BURNLEY, ENGLAND - FEBRUARY 12: Joey Barton of Burnley pulls back Nemanja Matic of Chelsea during the Premier League match between Burnley and Chelsea at Turf Moor on February 12, 2017 in Burnley, England. (Photo by Mike Hewitt/Getty Images) (Photo: Getty) 
Burnley were in the ascendancy and so nearly took the lead after 36 minutes when George Boyd and Barton combined to set up Matt Lowton. 
Lowton raced into the Chelsea box but his low shot was brilliantly blocked by Courtois. That was a huge moment in the match. Courtois also made another smart save from Andre Gray two minutes after the restart. 
Chelsea had a lot of possession in the second half but they barely tested Burnley keeper Tom Heaton as centre half Michael Keane marshalled the home defence superbly. 
Burnley were definitely worth their point and if they survive it will be the first time they stay up in the top flight since 1976. And that is almost as much an achievement for Burnley boss Sean Dyche as winning the title will be for Conte. poll loading Will anyone catch Chelsea now? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
